EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

****Accidental Release Prevention Policies at the Martinez Catalyst Plant (MZ)

The Martinez Catalyst Plant (MZ) is part of Shell Chemical LP and Shell Catalysts & Technologies. MZ is committed to being a responsible member of the Martinez and greater Contra Costa County communities. We place a high priority on operating our facility in a safe, healthful, and environmentally sound manner.

Shell requirements dictate their facilities continually identify methods to reduce the use of hazardous materials, evaluate risk, and reduce the risk to the community and environment through implementation of process design, engineering controls, and safe work practices and procedures. This commitment to healthy, safe, secure and environmentally sound operations is documented in the Shell HSSE (Health, Safety, Security, and the Environment) Commitment and Policy (Attachment 1). The MZ Risk Management Program (RMP) is incorporated into this HSSE Commitment and Policy through the MZ Health, Safety, Security, and Environmental Management System or HSSE-MS. Specific Plant RMP-related action items are identified, evaluated, resourced, and checked via an action tracking tool. These documents, as well as other related materials are readily available to all workers.

MZ stresses safe, healthful, secure, and environmentally sound operations via an annual employee training program and various safety meetings. MZ has a Health, Safety, Security, and Environmental (HSSE) and Administrative Procedures Manual that comprehensively covers various aspects of management systems conformance. Each employee and field contractor at MZ also receive a Basic HSSE Requirements Handbook. Shell also maintains internal HSSE Audit and Management Review programs under its HSSE-MS. Plant, Corporate, and Contract Personnel conduct internal audits at various time intervals (weekly to once every 3-5 years). Management reviews occur continually throughout the year and are formalized annually.

****

A Description of the Martinez Catalyst Plant and the Regulated Substances Handled

MZ consists of 2 main batch processes: Ethylene Oxide (EO) Catalyst and RM-17. The EO Catalyst Process produces a silver-based catalyst sold to industrial customers that convert hydrocarbons to ethylene oxide. A specially formulated impregnating solution is produced at MZ and absorbed onto carrier pellets to make the EO Catalyst products. 

MZ has a selective catalyst reduction (SCR) process to reduce emissions of oxides of nitrogen (NOx) from the EO Catalyst Process and associated pollution abatement devices. As part of this system, MZ has an aqueous ammonia addition system, consisting of a storage tank, unloading station with pump, and transfer system with pumps and filters. In this operation, aqueous ammonia is pumped, filtered, and directly injected into the process gas stream to convert NOx into nitrogen and water prior to discharge to the atmosphere. The aqueous ammonia is consumed in the process. This system uses tank (393V), which is purposed for aqueous ammonia service. The aqueous ammonia system unloading pump and supply pumps have been specified for the aqueous ammonia system. 

The RM-17 product is manufactured by reacting a proprietary raw material (containing toluene as a carrier) with a heavy olefin in the presence of a liquid catalyst. A series of simple distillation steps removes the lighter boiling components (including the toluene). The purified product is then shipped to other Shell Chemical facilities for further use in the process of manufacturing detergent products.

Please note for the purposes of this CalARP document, accidental release scenarios have only been determined for CalARP regulated substances. However, the management system, prevention program, and emergency response elements discussed later in the document apply to the entire MZ Site.

****Accidental Release Management System Program/Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps 

**Management System
MZ has d

eveloped a formal Risk Management system based on CCPS Plant Guidelines for Technical Management of Chemical Process Safety and Shell HSSE-MS requirements. This system is designed to plan, organize, implement and control the risk management program elements. This management system satisfies the requirements of Section 2735.6 of the CalARP regulation and ensures the risk management program elements are developed and continually improved. Records associated with the prevention program elements are retained for a minimum of five years unless otherwise specified in the CalARP regulation. The management system activities are further discussed below.

	Planning MZ has an overall HSSE program policy that identifies the objectives of its HSSE programs. 
	Organizing  Individuals responsible for each risk management program element are designated. These general lines of authority and communication are shown below. Written requirements are contained for each OSHA/CalARP prevention element in MZ Written PSM Compliance Plan (located within MZs written Injury and Illness Prevention Plan under Procedure HSSE-002).
	Implementing  Each assigned OSHA PSM/CalARP focal point facilitates the implementation of their program element.
	Controlling  Members of management and the individuals responsible for each risk management prevention program element periodically conduct internal reviews or audits against the goals and objectives of the element. Annually, the procedures are reviewed and recertified to ensure they remain accurate and reflect the current practices. 
	Communication  When one element is changed, the individuals that are responsible for elements that may be impacted are contacted by the changing element manager and notified of the changes.

General Lines of OSHA PSM/CalARP Authority and Responsibility
	The Site Manager has overall management responsibility for the Cal-ARP Programs.
	The HSSE Manager oversees Cal-ARP compliance not otherwise delegated.  This perso

n provides administrative and technical assurance over the MZ CAL-ARP program.  This person also assumes the lead role regarding PSM Management, Application, Worker Participation, Process Safety Information, Incident Investigation (shared with the Production Manager), Emergency Planning and Response, Compliance Audits, and Trade Secrets.
	The Environmental Manager serves as the back-up to the HSSE Manager Role.
	The Production Manager assumes the lead role regarding Pre-Start-Up Safety Reviews of PSSRs, Hot Work Permits, and Incident Investigation (shared with HSSE Manager).
	The Training Lead assumes the lead role regarding Operation Procedures and Training of Operating Workers.
	The Technical Manager assumes the lead role for Process Safety Analysis or PHA, and Change Management.
	The Maintenance Manager assumes the lead role regarding Mechanical Integrity.

**Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
The process safety prevention programs described in the following section represent integrated administrative controls intended to ensure the safety of workers, the public, and the environment. Many of these prevention programs (e.g., process hazards analysis or PHAs, compliance audits, incident investigation) result in the development and implementation of additional safeguards (e.g., administrative and engineering controls). Those recommendations that are planned for implementation at MZ will be discussed in Planned Changes to Improve Safety Section. Those applicable safeguards are in place and serve to help prevent, detect, or mitigate accidental releases of Cal-ARP regulated substances are summarized below: 

Release Detection
	Process Alarms

Release Containment and Control
	Improved Process Controls for Both EO Catalyst Production Lines.
	Valves to Permit Isolation of the Process.
	Automated Shutdown Systems for Specific Process Parameters (e.g., high level, high temperature, etc.).
	Diking and Berms.
	Redundant Equipment.
	Relief Valves.	

Release Mitig

ation
	Fire Suppression and Extinguishing Systems.
	Deluge Systems (e.g., firewater).
	Trained Emergency Response Personnel (PBF).
	Various Personal Protective Equipment.

Seismic	
	Structural Upgrade- Building A.
	Construct Modernized EO Production Line That Meets Seismic Standards.
	Various EO and RM-17 Process Related Upgrades.
	Construction of New Packaging Facility (Sackett Hall)

****General Accidental Release Prevention Program for MZ

**Process Safety Information

Process Safety Information (PSI) development, dissemination, and use are vital to the operation of a stationary source and to an effective release prevention program. MZ personnel use information regarding chemical hazards, equipment specifications, and operating limits in daily and strategic decision-making. Accurate and complete information is readily accessible to Employees and Field Contractors is therefore a basic component of the OSHA PSM/CalARP prevention program.

Established practices ensure the original PSI was compiled in conjunction with the initial process hazard analyses (PHAs). These practices ensure relevant PSI is maintained current via the Management of Change (MOC), Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR), and other (e.g., hazard communication) programs. Hard copies of the PSI are maintained (in various forms) in the Operations Supervisors Office and the Administration Building. An electronic copy of much of the information is also available. Personnel have access to PSI information on a 24-hour basis. Accurate PSI is maintained for the life of the facility.

MZ has compiled PSI that satisfies the regulatory requirements of OSHA PSM and Section 2760.1 of the CalARP regulations. This information was compiled under the direction of the MZ HSSE Manager and specifically followed PSM/RMP PSI requirements. Various technical resources (Process Engineer, Plant Engineer, Control Systems Engineer, Operations Manager, Technical Manager and Maintenance Manager) made sure the level of scope

and the level of detail was appropriate to safe MZ operations. This PSI enables personnel involved in the operation of the process to identify and understand the hazards posed by those processes involving regulated substances such as ethylene diamine (EDA) and aqueous ammonia. 
Appropriate personnel from MZ verify the equipment complies with recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices. They also verify all equipment is designed, maintained, inspected, tested, and operated in a safe manner.

****PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS

By systematically examining and identifying process safety hazards associated with the operation of a covered process, MZ has been able to plan and take appropriate action to improve the safety of our workers, the community, and the environment. MZ has performed a PHA covering the EO Catalyst Process every 5 years since 1999, with the last one conducted in 2024. The PHA for the aqueous ammonia process was conducted in July 2017 and updated in 2019 and will be revalidated every five years thereafter.

The purpose of the PHA is to:

	Identify hazards.
	Identify credible human errors and/or equipment failures that could lead to an external event.
	Evaluate the likelihood and/or consequence of various scenarios.
	Determine if existing chemical specific prevention steps/controls are adequate, and, where existing controls are inadequate, identify additional steps that can be taken to control the hazard.

In accordance with Section 2760.2 of the CalARP regulations, MZ consulted with Contra Costa County Health Services Department (CCCHSD) and determined the guideword Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP) methodology was the approach best suited for the PHAs of the EO Catalyst and Aqueous Ammonia Processes. This methodology was chosen due to general Shell practice and the opinion HAZOPs provide an acceptable level of analysis detail.

The following objectives are addressed by the HAZOP:

	Identification of the hazards of the substance and

of the process.
	Identification of the applicable external events (including seismic- and security-related events) that could lead to a release.
	Identification of possible equipment failures or human errors that could lead to a fire or release.
	Evaluation of the consequences and likelihood of the accident scenarios.
	Evaluation of the safeguards used to prevent or mitigate failures or errors.
	Consideration of the steps needed to mitigate the risks, including changes needed to equipment design, operating procedures, process conditions, etc. A list of proposed (and prioritized) action items is then generated.

****The EO Catalyst Process HAZOP

HAZOP workshops are conducted by a multi-disciplinary team that systematically identifies hazards and operability problems by searching for deviations from the design intent of each portion of the process. The PHA team consists of personnel who have expertise in the engineering and process operations of the specific process being evaluated.  The team also included an outside facilitator who was knowledgeable in the HAZOP methodology.  These team members apply their experience and technical expertise during the PHA to achieve the objectives of the study.  The most recent Ethylene Oxide and Aqueous Ammonia PHA team included an outside contracted PHA Facilitator, Technical Manager, Process Engineer, Process Operators, USW Health & Safety Representative, Control Systems Engineer, Production Manager, and Shell Catalyst Process Safety Manager. The team considers the causes and consequences of these deviations to identify hazardous conditions and their consequences, lists existing safeguards, and makes recommendations for changes where appropriate. 

The team identified and evaluated hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures and made suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when actions are necessary. The HAZOP was documented and finalized on worksheets containing a

description of each process node and its design intent, a list of possible deviations, causes of deviations, consequences, safeguards, and required action items/investigations/questions for further study. These potential deviations were risk-ranked using the Shell Risk Assessment Matrix or RAM. Any identified action items are formally tracked using the Action Item Database or SPHERA software and resolved through the MZ HSSE-MS. OSHA guidance is followed regarding issue resolution. A similar team conducts the revalidation of the PHAs every five years. PHAs are also updated, as necessary, in conjunction with the RMP updates. This documentation will be maintained for the life of MZ.

**Seismic (External Events) Analysis
MZ is located near several faults. The Concord fault is within 2 miles of the site. The Green Valley fault is approximately 2.5 miles northeast of the site. The Hayward fault is within 12 miles of the site to the west. The Concord and Green Valley faults have a potential to create most of the earthquake concern for the site. The Green Valley-Concord fault has a 16 percent probability of one or more greater-than-6.7-magnitude earthquakes between 2014 and 2043, and the Rodgers Creek-Hayward fault has a 33 percent probability of one or more greater-than-6.7-magnitude earthquakes between 2014 and 2043. These faults, particularly the Concord fault, create most of the earthquake concern at the Martinez Site.

According to the ABAG (Associated Bay Area Government) Liquefaction Susceptibility Map, the potential for liquefaction at MZ is very low. The ground surface at MZ includes soils that have been disrupted, modified, removed, built over, or filled with crushed rock or other material resistant to weathering, such as blacktop (asphaltic compounds), concrete, or compacted gravel, sand, silt and clay. Soil conditions are considered to be alternating layers of claystone, siltstone, and sandstone varying from dense to very dense. Based on this information, the S

ite Coefficient is S1. Finally, based on the geology of MZ, the potential for landslide or settlement is minimal.

County guidelines were followed during the seismic assessment of the EDA and 19% Aqueous Ammonia storage tanks, the EDA and 19% Aqueous Ammonia charge pump, associated piping system and the Solution Preparation vessel. These are the only pieces of equipment within the EO Catalyst Process that contain EDA and 19% Aqueous Ammonia. The objective of the seismic assessment was to provide reasonable assurance a loss of primary containment of EDA or 19% Aqueous Ammonia would not occur as the result of a major earthquake. In addition, the following additional design practices or standards were used by MZ to identify and minimize the risk resulting from seismic hazards:

	Guidance for California Accidental Release Prevention (Cal-ARP) Program Seismic Assessments, prepared for the Administering Agency (AA) Subcommittee Region I Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), and prepared by CalARP Program Seismic Guidance Committee.
	California Building Code (1998).

The walk down inspection included a thorough assessment of the structural elements and non-structural equipment and components. The inspection addressed: 

	Potential areas of structural weakness due to design or construction deficiencies. This includes inadequate anchorage to foundations or support structures.
	Identification of damaged components.
	The overall extent of corrosion.
	Piping spans, flexibility, lateral support, and attachments to vessels.

A Consulting Engineering contractor performed and documented the seismic walkdown inspection at MZ in 1999, 2004 and 2019. The persons conducting this review were licensed California Engineers with experience in the methodologies and earthquake engineering procedures presented in CalARPs Seismic Assessment Guidelines document. 

Findings were recorded on worksheets and with a digital camera with audio recording capabilities to insure a well-docume

nted, complete walk-through inspection. The assessment findings can be classified into five main categories:

	Damaged Support Columns.
	Cracked concrete footings.
	Piping with inadequate or questionable lateral and vertical support.
	Corroded and/or damaged equipment.
	Maintain adequate freeboard height on tanks.

For a complete list of findings from the 2019 report and are in progress of completion. 

MZ performed a seismic assessment for the vessels in the A Tank Farm (389V, 390V, 391V, 392V, 393V and 438V) in 2002. The vessels were assessed against the 1998 CBC and ASCE Guidelines for Seismic Evaluation and Design of Petrochemical Facilities, 1997, and referencing 1992 RMPP and 1998 CAL ARP. As a result of the assessment, additional anchoring was installed on all six vessels and the fireproofing was replaced. This work was completed in 2003.

**Operating Procedures
Up-to-date and clearly written standard operating procedures and safe work practices ensure all applicable personnel will run MZ in a safe, consistent and prescribed manner proving them to be beneficial to release prevention. MZ developed a written operating procedures program, which satisfies the requirements of OSHA PSM and Section 2760.3 of the CalARP regulation. These standard operating procedures (SOPs) ensure written procedures/practices are developed, reviewed, implemented, and annually certified as reflective of current plant practice. These documents are primarily accessed online, although hard copies (including emergency procedures) are maintained in the Administration Building in case of a power outage. They may be found within MZ HSSE Procedures Manual and Operations Takeover Manuals and are available 24 hours a day. Information contained in these procedures includes:

	Steps for each of the following operating phases: initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, start-up following a turnaround, and safe work pra

ctices (lockout/tagout, confined space entry, line and equipment opening, etc.). The latter are covered by a Plant-wide safe work permit system. The appropriate safety issues are also highlighted on the permits.
	Tables including safe operating limits (i.e., minimum and maximum pressure temperature, flow, composition) and consequences of deviating outside those operating limits (Included in some procedures, full list of all Process related actionable alarms for the facility are kept in ESP tables);
	A troubleshooting guide explaining the steps to correct or avoid the consequences of deviating outside the identified operating limits, including initiation of emergency shutdown;
	HSSE sections which provide a brief description of the acutely hazardous chemicals and the associated hazards; engineering and administrative precautions (e.g., ventilation, personal protective equipment (PPE) used to prevent exposures); control measures to be taken if physical contact or airborne exposure occurs, and control of hazardous chemical inventory levels; and,
	A list of applicable safety systems (e.g., alarms, interlocks, emergency systems and shutdowns), their functions, and their set points.

Operating procedures (including applicable check sheets) were prepared by technical and hourly staff based on a careful review of each operating mode, recognition of the hazards involved, and the appropriate standard sequence of safe operating steps. These procedures are periodically reviewed and updated by staff and line personnel to reflect current practices.

The operating procedures (including applicable check sheets) are maintained current and accurate through regular review cycles, MOC reviews, and annual certification by Operations. The MOC procedure is also used to manage temporary operating procedures. The MOC review is dependent upon the complexity of the change and is performed as described in the MOC Procedure.
In the operating procedures portion of the covered process, there

are no tables or safe operating limits, troubleshooting guide, or a list of applicable safety systems as they apply. However, the above information is available in central Ensure Safe Production (ESP) tables and elsewhere for the EO process and the other (RM-17) process in the facility. 
Process related actionable alarms for the facility are kept in ESP tables. Parameters monitored for alarm conditions include level indicators, temperature indicators, and pressure indicators. The specific alarm conditions in the ESP tables are:
	Alarm values for High-High (HH), High (H), Low (L), and Low-Low (LL) deviations
	Shutdown (S/D) values for High and Low Triggers and for a General Trigger condition 
	Notes documenting the alarm strategy and intention

All of the alarms are evaluated for a root cause for the deviation from normal conditions. Steps are taken to alleviate the potential for undesirable consequences (release). Examples of actions taken for the EDA system include:
	Stop any transfers into the vessel or equalize vessel levels for high level
	Stop water addition and allow EDA to cool for high temperature
	Stop transfers into the tank and allow pressure to relieve via the PSV in event of high pressure

Examples of actions taken for the 19% Aqueous Ammonia process include:
	Verify the tank has sufficient level to receive a full truck load of aqueous ammonia prior to unloading.
	Inspect the offloading hose for defects and replace the gaskets in the camlock fittings with new EPDM gaskets prior to unloading.
	Flush the offloading hose with water prior to disconnecting.

**Training
MZ believes employees who clearly understand how to safely operate a process can significantly decrease the number and severity of incidents. Therefore, a thorough training program focused on specific operating procedures and safe work practices is a key element of an effective prevention program. 

MZs HSSE Department has developed a written training program to provide employees (th

ose involved with operating covered processes) with an understanding of the types and causes of potential incidents or deviations within the process, and the hazards associated with the process. The training program also instructs personnel how to operate the process within safe operating limits, and how to handle potential emergencies. The training program satisfies the requirements of Section 2760.4 of the CalARP regulation and is comprised of initial training, periodic refresher training, hazard-specific training based on MOCs, PSSRs, and other activities, and documentation. The main specific tools used for this purpose is the MZ Training Catalog and Shell Open University software package.

Operators receive initial training in safe work practices and basic operating principles prior to assignment. Specifically, new Operators receive initial training and Unit Qualification program. The Operators receive training specific to the operations of each process once they are assigned to a process. The training criteria is documented in job skill matrices list the knowledge required (e.g., safe operating limits, safety system set points) and demonstration skills (e.g., emergency shutdown, lockout/tagout procedures). Various means are used to verify competency, including written and oral examinations, demonstrations, and on-the-job training. Documentation of the training, certifications, and background information is forwarded to and maintained by the MZ Training Lead.

Operating procedures are now in a checklist format. Hence, refresher training on these procedures is easily accomplished by the Operator using the actual document in the field. This was developed with employee consultation and allows refresher training to be conducted at a minimum of every three years. Training documentation is provided through the Training Lead.  Detailed training may also be required as a result of a specific MOC or PSSR. Line Supervision is responsible for ensuring the necessary trainin

g is conducted prior to implementation of the change to satisfy the MOC and PSSR program requirements of OSHA PSM and Section 2760.6 and 2760.7 (respectively) of the CalARP regulation. 

**Mechanical Integrity (MI)
A well-established mechanical integrity (MI) program ensures equipment critical to process safety is fabricated to meet process specifications, installed correctly, and maintained in a safe operating condition. It also allows Maintenance Employees to proactively identify and correct equipment deficiencies to avoid associated incidents and down time. MZ has developed an MI program satisfying the requirements of OSHA PSM and Section 2760.5 of the CalARP regulation. The MI program applies to pressure vessels, heat exchangers, storage tanks, pumps, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, and any additional equipment deemed by Operations and Maintenance to be important to safety (e.g., fire protection equipment, specific pieces of rotating equipment, electrical equipment, and process controls).
 
*Standards and Specifications Used for Equipment Purchase. 
Shell maintains a comprehensive set of engineering standards for the specification, purchase and installation of pressure equipment, tankage, heat exchangers, relief systems, piping, pumps, electrical equipment, instrumentation, and structures. Equipment falls into one of these categories is specified in accordance with these standards by the Maintenance Manager or the Control Systems Engineer; with input from Operations, the Process Engineer, and the Maintenance Supervisor as appropriate. Equipment is purchased by the Warehouse Clerk in accordance with the specifications and at the direction of the Maintenance Manager or the Control Systems Engineer. Equipment is installed in accordance with the standards at the direction of the Maintenance Manager or the Control Systems Engineer. The Pressure Equipment Inspector, in accordance with plant inspection procedures, provides quality a

ssurance for the purchase and installation of pressure equipment, tankage, heat exchangers, relief equipment and piping. Quality assurance for the installation of electrical equipment and instrumentation is provided by adherence to testing procedures developed by the Control Systems Engineer. 

Some of the non-pressure equipment in the plant is specially engineered for its service. Shell Engineering Standards are used for specifying, purchasing, and installing such equipment where applicable (for example, standards for electrical motors are applicable), but not all aspects of the equipment design and installation are covered by Shell standards. In these cases, the Maintenance Manager and/or the Control Systems Engineer or an engineer working at their direction reviews equipment design.

*Inspection of Pressure Equipment. 
Pressure equipment includes pressure vessels, exchangers, air coolers, piping, relief devices, tanks, and some non-pressurized equipment including cooling water towers, thermal oxidizers, flares, and process heaters. The Pressure Equipment Inspector is certified to API 510 (Pressure Equipment), API 570 (Piping), and API 653 (Tanks), and inspects equipment in accordance with these standards, as well as other equipment-specific recommended practices, Shell written best practices, and MZ HSSE Procedures. The Pressure Equipment Inspector maintains a record of each inspection and schedules future ones. Inspection documentation is maintained for the life of the equipment. The Maintenance Manager reviews unusual inspection results. The Maintenance Manager and Technical Manager work with the Pressure Equipment Inspector to ensure inspections are completed as required, documentation is completed, and inspection results are considered in setting inspection intervals. The frequency of inspections varies based on a risk-based algorithm developed and used by Shell. Equipment that is deteriorated beyond acceptable limits is repaired or retired.

*Written Mainten

ance Procedures. 
Written general maintenance procedures are contained in the HSSE procedures manual and are reviewed on a periodic basis by technical staff. These procedures outline the maintenance organization, workflow, and address specific maintenance functions. Maintenance on non-pressure equipment is performed in accordance with the original equipment manufacturers instructions or industry best practices. Maintenance on non-pressure equipment may be contracted by the Maintenance Supervisor to service companies that specialize in maintenance of specific equipment. Written maintenance procedures are reviewed and updated every three years. The maintenance procedures specify the date of the last update as well as when the next three-year update is due.

*Inspection and Maintenance Practices to Maintain Integrity of Structural Components. 
MZ vessel inspection procedures include requirements for inspection of structural components and fireproofing at each external inspection. Significant maintenance work has been completed on replacement of deteriorated fireproofing in the plant. 

*Maintenance Employee Training. 
MZ develops and qualifies its maintenance personnel and provides training on specific equipment and processes. MZ carefully assesses each applicant for employment and only hires maintenance personnel with skills and knowledge pertinent to their required job tasks. MZ has access to documentation of skills training for maintenance and contractor personnel. Maintenance personnel are also provided with an overview of the process, the hazards associated with the process, and general safe work practices. The Training Lead maintains initial and annual training records including content of training, Instructor, and means used to verify competency for Maintenance Employees. Maintenance Contractors provide applicable HSSE training records for their employees to MZ as necessary.

Records of maintenance work are stored in a computer program (Plant Maintenance (PM)

under the Logistics subcategory in the SAP Maintenance Manager) that is linked to the purchase of parts. Inspection records and remaining life calculations for pressure equipment are stored in a separate computer program. HSSE procedures are available electronically on the local web site. 

**Change Management
Process changes are sometimes necessary to address safety, environmental, and operational concerns. A change made in one part of a process may have unintended effects on other parts because the process is an integrated operation. Changes are therefore appropriately scrutinized before they are made to ensure the changes do not compromise the safety and integrity of the process, and to avoid adverse effects to worker and public safety and the environment.

MZ has developed a written Change Management Procedure (PIMZ Procedure PIMZ HSSE-150) that satisfies the requirements of OSHA PSM and Section 2760.6 of the CalARP regulations. The Production Manager identifies required training and the employees who must receive the training to operate the covered process with new changes. Communication of the changes and required training of affected employees is completed prior to the start-up of the impacted process. During the Change Management process, a document update plan, which includes PSI, operating procedures, etc., is developed and executed. The Change Management Procedure includes a form that requires specific technical and process information regarding a proposed change, as well as required authorization signatures from the Production Manager or the HSSE Manager, as applicable. The following list describes applicable changes that are managed by the Change Management Procedure:

Process and Operating Changes
	Temporary Process Changes
	Utilities
	Feedstocks
	Operating Procedures
	Kinetics and Process Chemistry
	Heat and Temperature Balance
	New Process Chemical or Alternate Supplier
	Key ESP values
	Staff Changes

Facilities Changes
	Deferred Maintenan

ce
	Equipment and Piping
	Instruments
	Materials Changes
	Temporary Bypassing of Equipment
	Temporary Bypassing of Protective Instruments
	Temporary Facilities
	Temporary Repairs
	Structural
	Pressure Relief or Venting
	Fire Protection or Emergency Systems
	Removal of Facilities from Service
	Change in Project Scope or Design

This Procedure does not apply to replacement in kind which is defined as replacements that satisfy the design specifications. This Procedure also does not apply to routine maintenance. 

The Technical Manager maintains the MOC records and documentation of completion of the recommendations for a minimum of five years.

The Change Management Procedure includes a Health, Safety, Environmental, and Operability (HSEO) Review Checklist, which is used to assess each change to the covered process and determine whether the change triggers a revised PHA. 

**Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)
MZ includes three OSHA PSM or EPA RMP processes. Modifications to these processes are sometimes required to improve safety and operability. When these modifications include: New facilities, any equipment or processes modified via a Management of Change, existing facilities which have undergone significant maintenance activities, or existing facilities which are being restarted after an extended downtime employees formally verify all controls (engineering and administrative) are installed and implemented prior to startup. MZ has developed a written PSSR procedure and specific checklists satisfy the requirements of OSHA PSM and Section 2760.7 of the CalARP regulation. 

The PSSR Procedure confirms the following prior to the introduction of regulated substances:
	Construction and equipment are in accordance with design specifications;
	Safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate;
	For new processes, a PHA has been performed and recommendations have been resolved or implemented before startup;
	For modified proc

esses, the requirements contained in the written MOC program have been met; and,
	Training of each employee involved in operating the new or modified process has been completed.

When changes in covered processes are identified or planned by MZ personnel, they must assess whether a PSSR should be performed. This assessment is conducted as part of the written MOC and PSSR procedures. In addition, appropriate personnel (e.g., Production Manager) review capital projects to ensure PSSRs are initiated when new or significantly modified covered processes are installed. 

The PSSR checklists were developed to facilitate the PSSR and to document all of the requirements have been addressed prior to the introduction of hazardous substances. Operations, Maintenance, Plant Engineering, and Process Engineering ensure the following steps are taken prior to startup:

	A review of the design specifications is conducted for the new or modified equipment and construction. These design specifications are verified against the equipment specifications documented in the written mechanical integrity (MI) program, and the design codes and standards and generally accepted good engineering practices included in the PSI element. 
	The safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are revised or developed as necessary in accordance with the written operating procedure, mechanical integrity, and emergency response elements. 
	For newly constructed processes, the piping and instrumentation diagrams (P&IDs) are complete and a PHA is performed. The recommendations from the PHA must also be resolved or implemented prior to start-up. 
	For modified processes, the P&IDs are updated. The recommendations previously formulated during incident investigations, compliance audits, and PHAs are reviewed to determine the effects of the modification. 
	If employee (e.g., operators and individuals performing routine and non-routine tasks) job tasks will be affected, training is conducted in acc

ordance with training and other PSM elements.

The appropriate personnel (Production Manager, Maintenance Supervisor, Maintenance Planner, Instrument Technician, and/or Pressure Equipment Inspector) review the completed PSSR review form and perform a physical walk-through inspection before authorizing startup. This ensures the PSSR process has been completed properly and all necessary precautions have been taken to mitigate a potential for release of covered chemical. This PSSR review form includes items such as:
	Isolation Points, PRVs, and instrumentation returned to normal operating state
	Vents and drains closed; plugs and caps installed on the vents and drains
	Rotating equipment lubricated, reconnected, and checked
	Steam lines bled of condensate; steam supply and condensate lineups complete
	Pressure gauges, temperature gauges, and programmable logic controller (PLC) and distributed control system (DCS) displays readable and working
	Fugitive emissions testing opened for maintenance or isolation scheduled within 90 days after startup.

The Production Manager tracks the PSSR records and documentation. PSSR records and documentation of completion of the recommendations are maintained for a minimum of five years.

**Compliance Audits
Ensuring the PSM/CalARP release prevention program elements are functioning properly (i.e., they are complete, current, and applied in compliance with company policy, regulations, and good process safety practices) is vital to the continual improvement of the process safety and HSSE programs. Internal compliance audits are performed at least every three years to review and evaluate the written documentation/records and implementation of these programs. These audits are expected to last approximately 1-2 days. Potential areas that can be improved within the prevention program elements are identified and recommendations are formulated and implemented to ensure an effective and improved overall prevention program. The developed

compliance audits program satisfies the regulatory requirements of Section 2760.8 of the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) regulation and the OSHA Process Safety Management Standard. PSM/RMP Compliance audits were conducted and certified in 1995, 1998, 2000, 2003, 2005, 2008, 2011, 2014, 2017, 2020 and 2023.

Audit Team members develop a list of recommendations for improvement. The results of the compliance audit are then communicated to interested personnel and contractors via established Plant communications channels (including the MZ HSSE Committee). The HSSE Manager then reviews the recommendations, determines the appropriate resolution of each recommendation, and assign responsibility for each recommendation. The HSSE Manager is also responsible for compiling periodic status reports for the recommendations and maintaining the associated records. Recommendations are tracked to completion. 

**Incident Investigation
MZ believes incident investigation is vital to the overall OSHA PSM/CalARP prevention program. MZ has developed an incident investigation procedure that satisfies the requirements of OSHA PSM and Section 2760.9 of the CalARP regulation. Its purpose is to investigate each incident that resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in, a release of EDA or 19% Aqueous Ammonia, or any other acutely hazardous materials that could have caused personnel injury or major property damage. Personnel identify underlying cause(s) and develop and implement corrective actions to prevent reoccurrence of the incident or similar incidents. A proximate cause analysis is performed for significant incidents (e.g., onsite fatality, significant offsite health effects). 

MZ management has stressed to employees the importance of reporting all PSM and other near-miss situations. A PSM near miss is an incident that could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release. Employees are reminded that the proximate cause(s) of minor incidents and PSM near misse

s could result in major incidents if uncorrected. Employees are encouraged to report minor incidents and PSM near misses to Supervision or HSSE either verbally, in writing, or anonymously.

The PIMZ General Manager or MZ Production Manager determines whether an incident investigation is warranted and charters a team to do the work. MZ uses root-cause methodology and analysis, and employees are appropriately trained.

A person trained in root cause techniques (e.g. Tripod, etc.) assumes the position of incident investigation team leader when an incident occurs. The number and experience of the team members is dependent upon the severity and complexity of the incident. Typically, the incident investigation teams are comprised of a team leader, an expert in the process, and other employees (including contract employees as applicable) knowledgeable in the operation, design, and maintenance of the process. The team members are trained in the incident investigation process and requirements. The incident investigation team leader is responsible for initiating the investigation as soon as possible, but definitely within 48 hours of the time of the incident or PSM near miss. 

The incident investigation involves four stages. The HSSE Manager oversees the completion of these four stages, and the Line Manager has the operational responsibility for these stages. The other team members are responsible for participating and taking direction at the stages as requested relying on their training and experience: 
	Gathering evidence (involves interviewing witnesses, taking photographs, collecting evidence and records, and obtaining samples as applicable); 
	Analyzing the evidence (also involves identification of root cause if a root cause analysis was performed);
	Developing conclusions; and
	Formulating recommendations

The incident investigation team prepares a written report at the conclusion of the investigation that includes (as applicable) a completed root cause information

, required action items, or other applicable items. Recommendations are developed as part of a root cause analysis. Items are discussed individually and as part of Management meetings. Recommendations that result from the incident investigation are entered into the SPHERA System or Action Item Database, where an employee is assigned to the corrective action for the recommendation and is responsible for the closure of the recommendation by the assigned due date. Recommendations from the incident investigation will be communicated through a variety of meetings (HSSE Committee, Employee Team Meetings Leadership Team, Plant Manager update) to the employees (including contractors), the county, the public, and the surrounding neighbors as applicable to the incident. 

An incident investigation report includes:
	Description
	Status
	Responsible Department
	Event Type
	Incident Sub Types
	Responsible Supervisor
	Date of Incident
	Date Reported
	Created By
	Date Created
	Lasted Updated By
	Last Update
	Immediate Actions Taken
	Activity Types
	Location
	For any qualifying CalARP incidents, any additional information listed in California Code of Regulations Chapter 19 Section 2750.9(b) relating to CalARP.

**Employee Participation
MZ relies on the expertise of employees (including hourly and contract employees) at all levels and disciplines to optimize operations and safety and maintain an effective release prevention program. This is achieved by consulting with (i.e., exchanging information with, and soliciting input and participation from) personnel to ensure consideration of their knowledge and experience in all applicable areas of the prevention program. MZ has developed a written employee participation plan (HSSE-002) that satisfies the requirements of OSHA PSM and the requirements of Section 2760.1 of the CalARP regulation. The written employee participation plan (available in hard copy or through the local area network) ensures:

	Employees and their re

presentatives are consulted on the conduct and development of PHAs conducted to comply with OSHA PSM and Section 2760.2 of the CalARP regulation.
	Employees and their representatives are consulted on the development of all elements of the release prevention program, the hazard assessment performed in accordance with OSHA PSM and Sections 2750.1 through 2750.9 of the CalARP regulation, and the emergency response program developed in accordance with Section 2765.2 of the CalARP regulation. Examples of participation include:
1.	Operations and maintenance employees being actively involved in the development of procedures; 
2.	Operations and maintenance employees being integral members of the established incident investigation teams; and,
3.	Operations and maintenance employees being consulted regarding the appropriate type and frequency of training. 
	Employees and their representatives are provided access to PHAs, results of incident investigations, compliance audits, and other information required to be developed under the CalARP rule through the HSSE Department.

The MZ HSSE Committee discusses employee participation issues as part of their periodic meetings. Electronic copies of meeting minutes are posted onto the HSSE website and shared with workers in the field. Meeting minutes are retained for a minimum of 5 years. 
Hot Work Permits

Controlling ignition sources is vital to the MZs accidental release prevention program. Therefore, it is critical pertinent personnel are notified when hot work (any spark-producing operation including use of power tools, grinding, burning, welding, brazing) is to be performed and appropriate safety precautions are taken prior to initiation of the work. MZ has developed a hot work permit program satisfies the requirements of OSHA PSM and Section 2760.11 of the CalARP regulation. This program requires employees complete permits certifying the applicable portions of the fire prevention and protection requirements are implemented pr

the hazards and properly trained. Also, the flammable gas or vapor content in the air must be less than 0% of the lowest content that is flammable or explosive; 
	Combustible materials (including oil accumulations) in areas that will be exposed during hot work are protected or relocated;
	Proper fire extinguishing equipment is available to employees performing the hot work.

Fire Watch duties and responsibilities are listed on the back of the field copy of the Hot Work Permit. Personnel in the immediate work area are notified prior to initiation of the hot work to make them aware of the ignition source. This awareness allows applicable personnel to quickly contact the fire watch and personnel performing hot work when continued use of the source of ignition becomes hazardous. Safe access and egress are also discussed. 

**Contractors
MZ relies on contractors to supplement the existing workforce during routine operations, maintenance, turnarounds, and construction projects. MZ and all Contract Owners are jointly responsible for safety and must ensure Contractors are trained in and understand the following:
	Work practices necessary to perform the job;
	Hazards associated with a process;
	Applicable sections of the emergency response procedure; and,
	Applicable safe work practices. 

It is also critical Contractors:
	Follow MZs HSSE rules, including safe work practices, and
	Inform Shell of any unique hazards they introduce while performing their work.

MZ has developed a Contractor Program, satisfying the requirements of OSHA PSM and Section 2760.12 of the CalARP regulation, to ensure safety issues are addressed during contractor selection and the owner and contractor owner share responsibility for the safety of all employees (including Contractors). The Contractor Program is beneficial to release prevention because it thoroughly evaluates Contractors to ensure well-qualified, trained, and safe Contractors are used onsite.

MZ requires potential Contract Own

ers answer specific questions regarding their HSSE programs. For Contractors who manipulate process equipment, this is normally done with a web-based contractor grading service (ISN, Avetta, etc).  The MZ HSSE Department will review this information against established criteria (e.g., accident records, workers compensation factors, etc.). This information also includes data regarding any unique hazards that might be introduced during the course of their work. The MZ HSSE Department also updates the approved contractor list annually and performs periodic reviews of contractors throughout the calendar year after the annual review.
Field Contractor Employees who touch process equipment are required to receive basic training through an approved external industry-sponsored provider before being allowed on site. In addition, Field Contract Employees receive a site-specific HSSE orientation and the Leadership Team Safety Engagement before they begin work. This orientation covers site hazards, process safety basics, and emergency issues including emergency notification, emergency access, muster points, shelter-in-place, and egress and evacuation routes. This orientation, which is repeated annually, includes a video, test and issuance of the MZ Basic HSSE Requirements Handbook. Field contractors who have completed MZ-specific training are provided with an identification sticker for their hard hats.

The HSSE Department reviews selected Contractors and their performance as part of a periodic review. MZ ensures proper training is provided, and documentation maintained for each contractor.

MZ has compiled a five-year accident history for all accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. 750.9 of the CalARP regulation. ****THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Overall safety at MZ is governed not only by the ability to prevent accidental releases of regulated substances from occurring, but also by the ability to mitigate any accidental releases. MZ has implemented an emergency response program to minimize the effects of accidental releases on employees, the public, and the environment. MZs emergency response program is covered under contract with the broader emergency action plan/emergency response plan (EAP/ERP) administered by the Martinez Refinery Company (PBF). The PBF EAP/ERP provides a complete range of emergency response services to MZ including a full incident command system, Auxiliary Fire Crew, a Hazardous Materials Team, a Confined Space Rescue Team, and an Emergency Medical Team (EMT). In addition:

	Resources from the Petrochemical Mutual Aid Organization (PMAO) are also available through PBF. PMAO is a Community Awareness and E

mergency Response (CAER) organization.
	MZ is located within the Contra Costa Fire District. Resources from this public agency would also be available during an emergency.
	MZ is subject to the Contra Costa County Hazardous Materials Area Plan. Initial Agency Incident Response, Incident Command, and Incident Control would come from the California Highway Patrol (CHP) and/or the Contra Costa Fire District (or their designees). The Contra Costa County Health Services Department Hazardous Materials Program Office (CCCHSD-HazMat) would normally be involved at the Incident Evaluation, Personnel Monitoring & Decontamination, Equipment Monitoring & Decontamination, and Public Safety & Information stages. Contra Costa Fire would arrange for any additional mutual aid resources under Management of Escalation.

The written EAP/ERP was previously submitted to CCCHSD under the Hazardous Materials Business Plan program. This plan satisfies the requirements of Title 8 California Code of Regulations (T8 CCR§3220); the Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) regulation T8 CCR §5192l; and Section 2765.1(b) of the CalARP regulation.

The EAP/ERP for PBF/MZ includes employee evacuation routes, head counting procedures, and training for employees. It also includes a notification list that provides the telephone numbers of agencies and individuals to contact in the event of one of several pre-identified emergencies (e.g., fire, employee injury, and employee fatality). The agencies and individuals represent local emergency responders (e.g., Fire Department), public notification and regulatory reporting requirements (e.g., CCCHSD), and internal notification (e.g., Site Manager, Corporate Headquarters). The notification list requires designated personnel make the notifications, and they document when the telephone calls were placed, and the name and position of the person contacted. Completed Notification Matrices are maintained for five years. 

MZ has available ba

sic firefighting equipment, such as fire extinguishers, hose reels, and fire monitors, as its chemical-specific mitigation equipment at MZ Site. Various personal protective equipment (e.g., chemical-resistant clothing, fire bunker gear, SCBAs, other respiratory protection, etc.) is also readily available. Properly trained employees can then respond to incipient fires after notifying PBF of the emergency. Specifics regarding fire brigade training and advanced chemical-specific mitigation equipment (e.g., fire trucks, foam tenders, HazMat Team gear, etc.) are available through the Martinez Refining Company.

Members of the PBF Health and Safety Department, Auxiliary Fire Crew, and/or the Response Action Team (RAT) periodically conduct familiarization tours or tabletop reviews of MZ facilities. A representative of the Contra Costa Fire District also inspects MZ periodically. Regular red tag or field simulation drills are conducted in the field to test operational response. A periodic emergency drill is also conducted by PBF in conjunction with various outside agencies. As appropriate, PBF, MZ, and/or the applicable emergency response agencies work together to resolve any deficiencies identified during the drill. This pre-planning activity ensures the members of the responding agencies are familiar with PBF/MZ facilities, the hazards of various extremely hazardous materials, the resources available at PBF/MZ, and their location. It also clearly identifies the capabilities and limitations of each responding agency. Copies of the drill records, including recommendations and critiques, are maintained at PBF and/or MZ.
 
MZ will also work closely with CCCHSD regarding any necessary response to hazardous material releases, to assist in determining requirements for downwind air monitoring, and to alert the public of the accidental release of EDA or 19% Aqueous Ammonia. PBF/MZ worked with CCCHSD to establish Telephone Emergency Network System (TENS) zones that will be notifi

ed of the incident through the Community Warning System for any Level 2 or 3 incidents. 
 
The emergency response program, including the EAP and the ERP, is reviewed annually to ensure it remains accurate and current. Employees are trained on the emergency response program when initially hired, when the emergency response plan is revised, and when employees responsibilities are changed. 

In addition, MZ workers receive a site-specific HSSE overview training on an annual basis. This orientation covers site-hazards, process safety basics, and emergency response program issues. The later includes emergency notification, emergency access, muster points, shelter-in-place, and possible evacuation routes (egress). This orientation is repeated annually. This training includes a video, a test and issuance of the MZ Basic Safety Requirements Handbook. Employees who have completed MZ-specific training are provided with an identification sticker for their hard hats. 

****Security Risk/Vulnerability Assessment (SRA)

The MZ Security Risk/Vulnerability Assessment (SRA) was performed during June 2022 by a team of security professionals and the HSSE Manager. The SRA is performed at least every five years. The SRA includes data gathering and analysis to assess security risks and to determine the need for upgrading countermeasures in support of the Shell security risk management program. The assessment was performed using the Shell Standard Risk Assessment Methodology. The Shell SRA methodology is consistent with the most current guidance available via API 780 Standard for SRA. The assessment is based on the collection of background information, an on-site survey, and the subsequent analysis of information. MZ HSSE also conducts a separate annual review of Site Security practices.
